question: Superior sulcus tumor of the lungs characteristically presents with:
exp: Ans: A. Ref: Robbins Pathologic Basis of Disease, 8th edition Explanation: Apical lung cancers in the superior pulmonary sulcus tend to invade the neural structures around the trachea, including the cervical sympathetic plexus. It produces a group of clinical findings that includes severe pain in the distribution of the ulnar nerve and Horner syndrome (enophthal- mos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the same side as the lesion. Such tumors are also referred to as Pancoast tumors.

question: Pancoast tumor is?
exp: Ans. is 'a' i.e., Superior sulcus tumor Pancoast tumor (pulmonary sulcus tumor or superior sulcus tumorlo It is a tumor of the pulmonary apex typically found in conjunction with a smoking history. It is situated at the top end of either the right or left lung.o Most Pancoast tumors are non-small cell cancers i.e. squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) or adenocarcinomaso It typically spreads to nearby tissues such as the ribs and vertebrae. The growing tumor can cause compression of a brachiocephalic vein, subclavian artery, phrenic nerve, recurrent laryngeal nerve, vagus nerveo Compression of a sympathetic ganglion resulting in a range of symptoms known as Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, hemianhidrosis, enophthalmos).
